description.plain:
Austin Richard Post (born July 4, 1995), better known by his stage name Post Malone, is an American rapper, singer, songwriter, record producer, and guitarist signed to Republic Records. Born in Syracuse, New York, and raised in Grapevine, Texas, Post Malone gained fame after releasing the single “White Iverson” on SoundCloud in February of 2015.

In an interview with Noisey, Post explains how he got his stage name:

I was looking for a name ‘cause I already have all these songs done and I couldn’t think of anything, so I put my name in a rap name generator and it said “Post Malone.”

Post discussed releasing a debut album in March of 2016, but after various setbacks, the album never came to fruition. In its place, on May 12th, 2016, he released his first mixtape, August 26th, to critical acclaim. He eventually released his debut album, Stoney, on December 9th, 2016. His follow-up, beerbongs & bentleys, was released on April 27, 2018, and became one of the biggest releases of the year, sealing Post’s superstar status.

Post’s third studio album, Hollywood’s Bleeding, was released on September 6, 2019, and became his second album to top the Billboard 200 charts. Post would yet again show his streaming dominance as the album boasted the most single-week streams of any album in 2019.

description.plain:
On “rockstar,” Post Malone compares his habits to the “live fast, die young” rock and roll lifestyle. Along the way, he references real events in rock history, name-drops Bon Scott and Jim Morrison, and highlights rockstar traditions like throwing TVs out of hotel windows.

Post previewed the song in December 2016, nine months before he released it, by posting a video of himself jamming to it in the studio. The preview received thousands of retweets on Twitter over the course of the year, so the track was highly anticipated by the time it finally dropped.

In late December of 2017, it was also revealed that Joey Bada$$ had co-written the track as well as penning an extra verse after Music Mafia leaked the original version of the song. This version also contained a verse from T-Pain, which he confirmed, in place of the 21 Savage’s contributions that ultimately appeared on the final version of the song.

On January 9, 2018, “rockstar” broke the record for holding the number one spot on Spotify’s Global chart with 108 days spent on the top of the list. The previous record holder was Ed Sheeran’s “Shape Of You.”

description.plain:
Virtually unknown before this track, Post Malone took the Internet by storm with “White Iverson,” a song filled with basketball metaphors.

In an interview with XXL, Malone said the track’s success was unexpected:

When I wrote it, I didn’t know that people [were] gonna fuck with it as much as I did. I didn’t plan on releasing it any time soon either, but it leaked somewhere and we just said ‘fuck it’ and recorded it.

Allen Iverson was heralded as one of the greatest players of his time. In his prime, he was considered one of the best players in the NBA, as reflected by his winning of the Most Valuable Player award in 2001.

Post explained his stage name at the Breakfast Club: Post is his real last name, and he made up the Malone part for practically no reason. However, Post has also said he got the idea for his stage name by entering his real name, Austin Post, into a rap name generator.

description.plain:
On “Congratulations,“ Post Malone and Quavo celebrate success, crediting it to their patience and hard work.

Malone debuted the track while performing in Austin, Texas in September of 2016, two months before the song’s official release.

description.plain:
“Psycho” is the third single from Post Malone’s long-awaited sophomore album, beerbongs & bentleys. Recruiting Ty Dolla $ign, the two sing about the luxuries they have earned such as convertibles, Audemars Piguet wristwatches, and other expensive jewelry. Post often raps about jewelry, and has posted on Quora to explain what drives him to do so:

When I was a little kid, I would rap about stuff that I wanted, like, “Hey, I’m working my ass off and I want this stuff in the future.” Because you’re not being braggadocious, but you’re still cool because you know what all this stuff is.

Post initially teased the song on January 4, 2017; over a year before its eventual release. Similar to how “rockstar” was teased, Post can be seen vibing to the song in the studio with a beer and a cigarette in hand. The track’s release date was announced when Post revealed he would tour North America in 2018.

“Psycho” debuted at #2 on the Billboard Hot 100, matching “rockstar” for Post Malone’s best debut on the Hot 100. Psycho’s debut at #2 also made Post Malone the ninth artist ever, and the second rapper, to have more than one song debut in the top 2 of the Billboard Hot 100. The song eventually peaked at #1 on June 11, 2018, marking Post’s second chart-topping song of his career and the first for Ty.

description.plain:
On “I Fall Apart,” Post reminisces about a heart break up he experienced in high school. The song was released as the sixth single from Stoney on October 17, 2017.

He jokingly mentioned in a Hot 97 interview that he “dove into his really emotional side” and even “cut himself to some records” in the album, and it shows in his lyrics.

description.plain:
“Circles” is the fourth single from Post Malone’s third studio album, Hollywood’s Bleeding. The track continues the heartbreak theme from “Goodbyes” as he struggles to maintain a strong relationship with this girl. Like “Goodbyes,” “Circles” fell victim to leaks before official announcements. A snippet of the track originally surfaced online in July of 2019, with the full song being leaked online later in August.

In 2018, Post released the song “Stay” in a very similar fashion—the song was debuted on April 4, 2018, during his first Bud Light Dive Bar Tour show in Nashville, Tennessee. Like “Stay,” “Circles” features a more unique instrumental compared to the majority of Post’s discography, and is sonically similar to his 2016 track, “Hollywood Dreams / Come Down.”

An official teaser was shared on August 5, 2019, and the full song was later debuted by Post during his Bud Light Dive Bar Tour performance on the same day in New York. During his performance at the Bud Light Dive Bar Tour, Post said that the track would be released the next week, leading many to believe it was supposed to be released on August 16. However, the song was not released on its original expected release date. In an Instagram post on August 28, 2019, Post announced the song would be released on August 30, 2019, alongside the song’s cover art.

description.plain:
On “Better Now,” Post reminisces about a past relationship.

He believes that his emotions mirror those of his ex. They are likely both masking the fact that they still have feelings for each other in an attempt to “win the breakup.”

description.plain:
“Wow.” is Post Malone’s first single for his third studio album, Hollywood’s Bleeding, and was also Post’s first release since his October 2018 collaboration with Swae Lee, “Sunflower.”

The song is thematically similar to “Congratulations,” a massive hit from his 2016 debut album Stoney which is even referenced in the second verse. Both songs focus on Post showing off his wealth, such as cars and money, to the people who doubted him before he was famous.

The cover art for Post’s collaboration with Young Thug, “Goodbyes,” has text that reads “Single 02,” suggesting “Wow.” is the first single from his third album. When “Wow.” was released, Post made significant changes to his social media accounts, most notably changing the color theme from yellow to blue. This change was representative of the color of his next album, which makes sense considering he shared thoughts of trying to release a new album back in November of 2018:

Trying to put out a new body of work before the end of the year but we all know how that goes wish me luck…

“Wow.” is Post Malone’s first single for his third studio album, Hollywood’s Bleeding, and was also Post’s first release since his October 2018 collaboration with Swae Lee, “Sunflower.”

The song is thematically similar to “Congratulations,” a massive hit from his 2016 debut album Stoney which is even referenced in the second verse. Both songs focus on Post showing off his wealth, such as cars and money, to the people who doubted him before he was famous.

The cover art for Post’s collaboration with Young Thug, “Goodbyes,” has text that reads “Single 02,” suggesting “Wow.” is the first single from his third album. When “Wow.” was released, Post made significant changes to his social media accounts, most notably changing the color theme from yellow to blue. This change was representative of the color of his next album, which makes sense considering he shared thoughts of trying to release a new album back in November of 2018:

Trying to put out a new body of work before the end of the year but we all know how that goes wish me luck…

description.plain:
“Stay” was the fourth song to be debuted from Post Malone’s sophomore album, beerbongs & bentleys. The song features a much slower tempo than the three previous singles, marking the first song that has “push[ed] the genre” on his sophomore album.

The song is about Post’s struggle to maintain a relationship with a girl. It’s possible Post wrote this song during the short time that he and his girlfriend, Ashlen, had separated.

The song was performed live as part of the Bud Light Dive Bar Tour in Nashville, Tennessee, before an exclusive preview was released by Yahoo!.

Genius also released a “Deconstructed” of Stay with it’s co-producer watt.

description.plain:
Produced by Louis Bell and Post himself, “Candy Paint” is a flex record from the Fate of the Furious soundtrack album. On October 19, 2017, however, Post re-released the song as the second single from his sophomore album, beerbongs & bentleys.

The song features the general theme of a hot whip with a candy-paint finish, along with references to Post’s wealth and success. Post himself has a custom Ford Explorer that has a blue candy-paint finish with “the white on top” and Lambo-style doors which inspired this song.



Post took the car onto the show, Inside West Coast Customs, in episode seven of the sixth season, titled “Post Malone’s Old Skool Explorer.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kg8pSo84orQ
(Video not available in certain countries.)

description.plain:
“Goodbyes” serves as the second single for Post Malone’s third studio album, Hollywood’s Bleeding. The track also marks his first single of 2019 and the first collaboration between Post and Young Thug. Throughout the song, Post sings about troubles with a girl and expresses his desire to remove her from his life, while Thug’s part seems to suggest that he’s trying to reconnect with a girl, which is in complete contrast to the rest of the song.

The music video for the track features Post being stabbed and killed in the very beginning. Throughout the remainder of the video, a zombified Post emerges from his grave and walks around the Wild West-like town where he comes across Young Thug singing to the same crowd that killed him earlier on. There, he confronts the girl who left him behind originally, which could be a reference to Post’s ex-girlfriend, Ashlen Diaz.

A snippet of the song originally surfaced online on March 12, 2019, and the full song leaked on March 14, 2019. After speculation by various media outlets, Post confirmed the track would be released on July 5, 2019, in a Twitter post.

description.plain:
The titular track of Post’s 2019 record is a commentary on the toxicity of the Hollywood lifestyle and the pitfalls of fame.

The song interpolates Michael Jackson’s “They Don’t Care About Us,” which is a plea against racism in modern society.  It’s the first MJ interpolation on the album — later track “Enemies” seems to interpolate Rockwell’s “Somebody’s Watching Me,” which features Jackson.

body.plain:
The titular track of Post’s 2019 record is a commentary on the toxicity of the Hollywood lifestyle and the pitfalls of fame.

The song interpolates Michael Jackson’s “They Don’t Care About Us,” which is a plea against racism in modern society.  It’s the first MJ interpolation on the album — later track “Enemies” seems to interpolate Rockwell’s “Somebody’s Watching Me,” which features Jackson.

description.plain:
“Paranoid” is the opening track to Post Malone’s long-awaited beerbongs & bentleys. Post details his doubts about his security and safety with his friends and his rise to fame. He feels as if people could be manipulating him for his fame and fortune and begins taking more precautions to protect himself.

This song could be influenced by the 2017 controversy in which infamous YouTuber, Jake Paul, uploaded a since-deleted video that initially contained footage of Post Malone’s private property after seeing his interview with H3H3 Productions in which Post criticized Paul’s single, “It’s Everyday Bro”, and then proceeded to purchase Paul’s merch for an ironic joke soon after.

description.plain:
On “Take What You Want,” Post Malone enlists the help of fellow rapper Travis Scott and iconic Black Sabbath rocker Ozzy, The Prince of Darkness, Osbourne. The artists take turns discussing a relationship with a girl who broke their hearts. Post’s verse focuses on the emotional baggage of his significant other.

While this marks the first time that either Post Malone or Travis Scott have worked with Ozzy, Post Malone has often expressed his fondness for heavy metal and even used to play in a hardcore band himself.

description.plain:
On “Over Now,” Post discusses breaking free from a bad relationship with a materialistic girl. While he was head over heels for her, he came to his senses and declares things to be “over now” and wishes her nothing but bad luck.

Due to the rock-like beat (with help on the drums from the lead drummer of Mötley Crüe, Tommy Lee) and more aggressive lyrics/vocals, “Over Now” certainly stands out amongst the other songs on Post’s hip-hop-dominant sophomore album.

description.plain:
“Too Young” is based on how Post Malone doesn’t want to die before he is wealthy and famous.

Also an ode to both A$AP Yams, Christian Taylor & Pimp C whom both died Too Young. This song is meant to “remind us that we can reach others with a different perspective and it can mean something to them as well. Everybody can relate to something in a certain way.” -Post Malone

description.plain:
“No Option” is Post Malone’s song to his haters and his fans about the lateness of his album.

In a heartfelt message on Instagram, he told his fans that his album was going to be postponed due to unforeseen complications. He personally apologized on behalf of himself and his team and expressed his displeasure at the setback.

Now that the album is out he now has time to flex on anyone who counted him out when Stoney got delayed, this is his time to shine and no ones getting in his way.

description.plain: “Die For Me” is a trap-pop banger that features Post and Future lamenting their relationships with untrustworthy women, while Halsey provides a women’s perspective on the bridge. It is Post Malone’s first collaboration with Halsey and his second with Future following the “Congratulations Remix.”

body.plain: “Die For Me” is a trap-pop banger that features Post and Future lamenting their relationships with untrustworthy women, while Halsey provides a women’s perspective on the bridge. It is Post Malone’s first collaboration with Halsey and his second with Future following the “Congratulations Remix.”

description.plain: “Rich & Sad” talks about Post’s life when he was going through a hard time with his girlfriend, Ashlen Nicole Diaz. While Post showcases his wealth on this track, he still felt lonely during that time when they weren’t together, which goes back to the famous phrase “money doesn’t buy happiness.” Despite his rise to stardom, Post still wished that she never left him.

description.plain:
“92 Explorer” is named after Post’s pimped out 1992 Ford Explorer which he had customized by West Coast Customs. Post had the idea to customize a ‘92 Explorer so he bought one for $1,700, and sent it to West Coast Customs who customized it.



The track was produced by Atlanta producer London on da Track and marks their first collaboration. Known for his work with Young Thug, Drake and T.I., London is widely regarded as one of the best producers in the game.

“92 Explorer” sees Post singing about the titular car and detailing his rockstar lifestyle as well as his spending habits.

description.plain:
“Ball For Me” sees Posty and Nicki detailing their excessive money spending and lavish lifestyles whilst using a variety of basketball motifs. Post also talks about his interactions with his materialistic partner.

The song marks the first time Post Malone and Nicki Minaj collaborated and was produced by Post’s frequent collaborator Louis Bell, who previously produced Post’s hits “rockstar” and “Congratulations.”

description.plain:
On “Saint-Tropez,” Post matches a refreshing flow with a funky trap beat. On the track, Post describes the lavish lifestyle he leads, dropping designer brand names such as Versace and Abercrombie & Fitch, without disregarding his work ethics that led to his success.

The track’s title is a French tourist destination known for its amazing beaches and rich lifestyle.

description.plain:
“Spoil My Night” is an upbeat first collaboration between Post Malone and Swae Lee.

Throughout the song, both artists detail nights filled with women and flexing their own money. Whenever women are around though, feelings seem to always interrupt a good time.

The song became the fifth track that fans got to hear before beerbongs & bentleys was released, as Post Malone debuted it during his set at Coachella 2018.

description.plain:
On “Otherside,” Post discusses his feelings of anguish for a girl that betrayed him. In the chorus, he describes how all of the alcohol and models in the world could not replace the girl who left him.

He also expresses his loss of faith in God. This is shown by his use of religious symbolism throughout the song, for example:

Say my prayers, but I lost faith a long time ago

The title of the song may be a nod to the Red Hot Chili Peppers' 1999 hit “Otherside.”

description.plain:
“Zack and Codeine” references the Disney Channel show The Suite Life of Zack and Cody. The show stars real-life twins Cole and Dylan Sprouse playing the titular twins as they live in a luxury hotel.

The hotel motif is apparent on the track, as Post raps about his raging life and the parties he throws in hotels. He plays on the homophone of Cody’s name and “codeine,” an opiate that is most often referenced in hip-hop due to its status as an ingredient for lean.

description.plain:
“A Thousand Bad Times” sees Post lamenting the failed relationships of his past, and wallowing in the idea that his situation won’t improve in the near future. Despite this melancholy tone, Post told Spotify that he sees the song as a general message of perseverance, encouraging the listener to fight through their hardest times to get to better circumstances.

Following its release, the song entered the Billboard Hot 100 at #29.

description.plain:
“Same Bitches” is Post Malone’s first collaborations with California rappers G-Eazy and YG.

The track revolves around women who don’t have a sense of self. They also tend to gravitate towards artists, such as the ones featured in this song, but the right girl wouldn’t be just like everyone else.

The song was first previewed through a snippet on Twitter as someone found a Postmates driver that was tipped with a copy of beerbongs & bentleys by Post Malone himself.

description.plain:
On the final song from ​beerbongs & bentleys and the third song in a row themed around cars, Post underscores his success by flexing about the vehicles he owns.

The title of the song is a play on the name of the Rolls Royce Wraith, but is also a homophone for “Sugar Ray” which likely refers to the 90’s American Rock band whose smash hit “Fly” Post interpolates in the chorus.

description.plain:
American artist Post Malone teams up with rising star DaBaby on “Enemies,” an introspective collaboration. Post discusses the way that mainstream fame has impacted his relationships and how he responds to the disloyalty, while DaBaby raps about his newfound success and sends a warning shot to his enemies.

DaBaby teased a portion of his verse and a snippet of the chorus on his Instagram account, an hour before the album’s release.

This track marks the first time that either Post Malone and DaBaby have worked together.

description.plain:
On “Blame It On Me,” Post reflects on the harsh consequences that follow the rap life. As the title suggests, Post blames himself for having to choose this lifestyle.

Post rapped about how fame impacted him in a different way on his hit “rockstar”:

I’ve been fuckin' hoes and poppin' pillies
Man, I feel just like a rockstar

description.plain:
“On The Road” is a defiant anthem between Post Malone, Lil Baby, and Meek Mill that sees the artists boasting about their incredible work ethic. Post’s verse accentuates his wisdom beyond his years, while Lil Baby and Meek Mill take time to delve into the fake friends who attempt to surround them and relationships with women.

Lil Baby teased a portion of his verse and a snippet of the chorus on his Instagram account, an hour before the song’s release.

This track marks the first collaboration between all three artists (and Post’s first with both featured rappers) but Baby and Meek are frequent collaborators and have worked together on tracks like May 2019’s “You Stay.”

description.plain:
As its title would suggest, “Takin' Shots” is a straightforward drinking song where Post also describes other aspects of his hedonistic lifestyle, including his drug habits and sexual escapades.

The song is also littered with pop-culture references, such as Jason Williams and possibly The Simpsons.

description.plain:
The entirety of “Broken Whiskey Glass” is sort of a blend of Post Malone’s love for hip-hop and rock music. He said in an interview:

I was really into rock, like Metallica and Megadeth. But also Ice T, N.W.A, Ice Cube, all that good stuff. I’m thankful that my dad put me onto music, and that he showed me a lot of music growing up. I was into everything. As I grew up, I got more into the folk vibe with Johnny Cash, Hank Sr., Charlie Feathers. I love every type of music. Whatever is on, I’ll rock with it.

The first half of the song has acoustic guitar chords played, by himself, in a slow tempo and with a heavy emphasis on Post’s singing. After the chorus, the instrumental changes to a more hip-hop style one and Post starts focusing more on rapping.

description.plain:
On “Allergic,” Post Malone contrasts an energetic beat with hard-hitting drums in the verses with slow guitar melodies during the chorus.

The track describes an “impossible love,” and Post details a toxic relationship which involves constantly breaking up and getting back together and drug use. Within the verses, Post reflects on the sad truth that his lover may be one of his demons.

The track is set to be sent to alternative radio on September 24, 2019 as the fourth single from Hollywood’s Bleeding, being the predecessor of “Circles,” released in back in late August this year.

description.plain:
“Money Made Me Do It” pays homage to Bankroll Fresh, an Atlanta rapper who was best known for his 2015 self-titled mixtape and his hit songs, “Walked In” and “Hot Boy”.

He was killed in a tragic shooting on the night of March 4, 2016, at the age of 29. The deadly scene occurred at Street Execs studio where dozens of shell casings were reportedly found. Many rappers have paid tribute in light of his death which include Lil Wayne, Pusha T, and even 2 Chainz himself.

2 months prior to the song’s release and a week after his untimely death occurred, he explained how the late MC’s passing affected him in an interview on The Wendy Williams Show:

He was an authentic trap rapper from Atlanta, who touched many lives and lit up every room he went to. It was super unfortunate, super unnecessary, super senseless. And it just made me want to step up and use my platform for more positivity.

description.plain:
“I’m Gonna Be” is a song about partying hard and letting loose. In the song, Post Malone makes constant references to how he doesn’t care about how people view him in an industry where people are constantly judging his every move.

The uplifting vibes of the song invite people to have some self confidence and get out there and do whatever you want without caring about how other people see you.

description.plain:
On the short yet impactful “Internet,” Post Malone details his frustrations with the internet in general, specifically targeting social media culture to parody.

The song was originally leaked online on September 15, 2018. This leak contained an open verse where the instrumental played before Post jumped back into the second chorus. A second version leaked online on May 24, 2019, featuring vocals from Kanye West; his verse was unfinished and merely served as a reference verse. Post confirmed in an interview with Kerwin Frost that the song dates as far back as 2016.

description.plain:
A surprise to some, “Up There” is produced by none other than the great  Pharrell Williams. Being that this is Malone’s debut album, this is truly impressive. The couple work together to create a wonderfully groovy track as Post’s easy-going voice and natural vibrato are only complimented by Pharrell’s production skills and melodic ad-libs.

The song discusses how Post feels about his partner; he feels she is disconnected from him. He doesn’t want to deal with it anymore and would rather get high and ignore his problems. He feels uncomfortable because he tells himself everything is alright, however, gets drunk and/or high to forget it all.

description.plain:
Post Malone officially released this song a day after it was leaked on the forum “Kanyetothe.com,” which subsequently inspired the artwork for the song. Since its release in 2015, the song has been played over 17 million times on Soundcloud, making it a popular track.

“What’s Up” is Post Malone talking about a relationship he’s attempting to have with a woman. He raps about the gifts he wants to give her and how he wants to treat her, but she seems apprehensive about the whole relationship. Post Malone simply wants to know, “What’s up?”

description.plain: “Myself” is a calm Post Malone track which reflects on his journey to stardom. A strong, catchy drumbeat dominates the track, as Post looks back on the realities of his success, which includes touring the world and spending excess amounts of money.

description.plain: “I Know” is the penultimate song on Post Malone’s 2019 album, Hollywood’s Bleeding. On the track, Post pairs a catchy flow with soft percussion and explores the outcome of a broken relationship, focusing on his disappointment in the success of the relationship.

description.plain:
“Hit This Hard” details the fast lifestyle and sleepless nights, fueled by drug consumption and partying, that Post has been living. Coupled with the regrets and self reflection that come with falling into the hole of drug and alcohol usage, Post questions if this lifestyle is good for him before immediately jumping right back into it.

The ambient, atmospheric, and psychedelic beat (co-produced by Illangelo, who lead the production on all 3 of The Weeknd’s mixtapes back in 2011) contrast the distorted, high pitched, and warped vocals throughout the intro and pre-choruses. The influence of the producer can truly be felt, as Post taps into The Weeknd’s style.

description.plain:
“TEAR$” was released on SoundCloud by Post Malone in 2015. The track quickly blew up and currently has over 11.7 million plays on SoundCloud.

Post Malone is describing how he can use his finances due to his insane wealth. “TEAR$” is his description of what it feels like for him living life without sadness from the money he possesses.

description.plain:
“Jonestown” references the infamous Jonestown cult massacre. Jonestown was located in Guyana: the residence of the Peoples Temple, an American cult led by and named after Reverend Jim Jones.

The phrase “drink the Kool-Aid” refers to blindly trusting something that may have devastating consequences. It can be traced back to the Jonestown massacre, where Jim Jones convinced his congregation to drink ‘Kool-Aid’ (which was actually grape Flavor Aid) poisoned with cyanide that resulted in 909 casualties. Historians debate whether this was an act of mass murder or mass suicide.

description.plain:
The 8th track on Post’s 2016 mixtape August 26th, this two-part track is a fan favorite because of the mix of genres offered.

Part I, “Hollywood Dreams”, is a partial cover of “Dreams” by Fleetwood Mac. The soft rock vibe offers a relaxing sound while Post sings about the party lifestyle he’s grown accustomed to in LA.

Part II, “Come Down,” is a heavy trap track with a darker instrumental and vibe. Post makes this a more emotional track where he seems to come down from his high that Part I represents.

description.plain:
“No Reason” is the name given to a series of unreleased collaborations between Post Malone, Kanye West and Justin Bieber. This first version is the shortest of the three, featuring fewer vocals than both the second version and the rumored third version. Post can be heard mumbling towards the end of his verse, suggesting that he never actually finished it.

The song was auctioned by Music Mafia and surfaced online almost a year later on August 31, 2018. Prior to this, the majority of the song had only been made available in low-quality thanks to the buyer leaking snippets of it.

Long before the song entered circulation, a low-quality snippet of Kanye’s verse appeared online. The verse features mostly mumbling from Kanye, however, because it was unfinished, and it appears only on the second version of the song.

description.plain:
“Boy Bandz” is Post Malone’s braggadocious statement he has money by the bands and spends it on clothes, and jewelry. He further describes how his jewelry glistens and jumps around with an analogy to the popular late-‘90s boy band *NSYNC.

The song is found to resemble grunge type music with his vocal style and it’s distorted bass line.

description.plain: Future hops on the official remix of the Post Malone and Quavo-assisted hit single “Congratulations.” The Metro Boomin, Louis Bell & Frank Dukes produced track sounds a bit different from the original. With snaps added and different drum patterns throughout Future, Quavo & Post’s verses, as well as ad-libs from Future and gets the signature “Metro Boomin want some more nigga” tag in the intro and Metro’s other signature tag “If Young Metro don’t trust you, I’m gon' shoot you” during the outro.

description.plain:
Post Malone and his friend Jason Stokes, or “Jazzy Eff” (also known as YouTuber MinecraftUniverse) made this song (and video to go with it) when he was 17 years old for art class.

The character “Leon DeChino” he uses in this song is referenced in a handful of Post’s other songs such as “Psycho” and “Patient.” No one knows what DeChino is doing nowadays, but according to Post, he is “getting mad bitches.”

description.plain:
Featuring T-Pain and Joey Bada$$, this version of Post Malone’s hit song, “rockstar,” was leaked on December 27, 2017, by Music Mafia. The track features verses from Joey and T-Pain in place of 21, as well as a slightly different intro and instrumental piano.

Though Music Mafia released this under the guise of it being a remix, this is actually the original version of the song according to T-Pain. Joey also tweeted that he co-wrote “rockstar” with Post, and Post has said before that Joey wrote a verse when the track was being created.

description.plain:
“Spaceships on Sunsets” is an unreleased collaboration between Post Malone and Trae Tha Truth, produced by frequent-collaborator Fki 1st.

Not much is known about the song other than speculations; reports by people online have suggested that the song was made during sessions for Post’s debut album, Stoney (due to its similarity in style to songs on his mixtape, August 26th), but it was unused.

Snippets of the song have been around since as early as July 2016 under the name “Sunsets,” and later came into heavy circulation before being leaked in its entirety on December 3, 2017.

YouTube and SoundCloud uploads began to be taken down by Universal Music Group from February 16, 2018, confirming the name of the song to be “Spaceships on Sunsets.”

description.plain:
This is an early version of the “Internet” from Post Malone’s 2019 effort, Hollywood’s Bleeding, featuring reference vocals from Kanye West that leaked on May 24, 2019.

In an interview with HipHopDX in December 2016, Post mentioned a potential Kanye West feature being left off of his debut album, Stoney. It’s possible that it was this song.

As is typical with many demos, the track finds Kanye mumbling as he attempts to lay down the melody. Judging by comments from Post in an interview, it’s likely that Kanye laid down these vocals for Post to work with and were simply left on this demo.

description.plain:
“Writing on the Wall” is a collaboration between Post Malone, French Montana, Cardi B and Rvssian that appears on French’s 2019 effort, MONTANA. This is an early version of the song featuring Zuse that leaked online on June 4, 2019.

Recorded in 2016, the song was seemingly shelved, albeit not forgotten about. In April 2019, the song could be heard playing in the background of a video shoot for French, Post and Cardi. It later saw an official release on September 27, 2019.

This version of the track features a slightly different instrumental, as well as some extra vocals from Post and Zuse cut from the final release.

description.plain:
“Remember” is a leaked demo from Post Malone. Its producer and time of recording are unknown. Judging by the style of production, it appears to be a leftover from beerbongs & bentleys, however, this is unconfirmed; Post himself even addressed the leak, calling the song “really old.”



Throughout the unfinished song, which lacks a second verse, Post talks about his detractors on his rise to fame in a similar fashion to “Congratulations.” It leaked online on November 9, 2018.

description.plain:
“No Reason” is the name given to a series of unreleased collaborations between Post Malone, Kanye West and Justin Bieber. In comparison to initial leak, this version contains a verse by Kanye, as well as differing vocals from both Post and Bieber and a slightly alternate instrumental.

As is typical with many demos, both Post and Kanye can be heard mumbling throughout their verses. It’s likely the track was never finished.

Long before the first version of the song entered circulation, a low-quality snippet of Kanye’s verse appeared online. It leaked in full on November 6, 2018.

description.plain:
“Kurt Cobain” is an unreleased collaboration between Rich The Kid and Post Malone. It leaked online on December 7, 2019.

The track was first previewed in mid-2017 by Rich The Kid, however, it never saw an official release. A high quality snippet was later leaked by Music Mafia almost a year later. It appears that there are multiple versions of the song; the lyrics found in the initial snippet don’t appear on the leaked track.

description.plain: “Easier” is an unreleased throwaway demo by Post Malone. It’s unfinished, featuring Post mumble as he attempts to lay down the melody. Details about the song are largely speculative, however, it’s thought to have been recorded sometime around or after sessions for Post’s 2018 release, beerbongs & bentleys. It leaked online on August 11, 2019.

description.plain:
“Red Wine and White Sheets” is an unreleased throwaway by Post Malone. It finds him singing to a lover over a piano-driven instrumental by Zaytoven.

In an interview with ShayDiddyTV, Post announced the title of the song and said that it was inspired by R. Kelly. He also explained that it was considered for Stoney, but it was ultimately left off the project.

The song was put up for auction by Music Mafia on March 11, 2018, under the name “Red Wine”. It leaked online on November 5, 2018.

description.plain:
“Overtones” is an unreleased throwaway demo by Post Malone. It’s unfinished, featuring Post mumbling as he attempts to lay down a rough idea for the track. The track is thought to have been recorded in 2017 during sessions for Post’s 2018 album, beerbongs & bentleys. It leaked online on February 8, 2020.

The track features similar production elements to the Hollywood’s Bleeding track, “I Know,” and is thus presumed to be produced by Post’s frequent collaborator, Louis Bell. The track also features similar FX effects to another mumble-demo by Post, “Easier,” which leaked in August, 2019.

description.plain:
“Trembling” is the name given to a leaked song by Post Malone. The song is very rough, featuring Post mumble through the track as he attempts to create a flow.

It’s unknown when the song was recorded, however, judging by the style of production, it could’ve been leftover from beerbongs & bentleys. It leaked online on January 19, 2019.

description.plain:
“Santa Fe” is a song that was released by Post Malone on August 23, 2014, but has since been deleted for unknown reasons.

On December 8, 2015, the song resurfaced online through SoundCloud but has yet to be officially released by Post himself.

description.plain: “Honest” is an unreleased throwaway demo by Post Malone, presumably recorded sometime around or after sessions for beerbongs & bentleys. description.plain:
“Wake Me Up” is a leaked song by Post Malone. The song is very rough, featuring Post mumble through the track as he attempts to create a flow.

The leaked file was dated 2016, and seems consistent with how Post’s voice sounded in late-2015 through 2016. It leaked online on September 20, 2018.

description.plain: “Me Or Us” is a track by Young Thug that appears on his 2017 effort, BEAUTIFUL THUGGER GIRLS. In an interview with DJ Booth, producer Charlie Handsome confirmed that Post Malone recorded some vocals for the song back in 2015. As is typical with many demos, Post mumbles a fair bit as he attempts to lay down a melody. The vocals surfaced online on July 25, 2019.

description.plain: “The One” is an unreleased throwaway demo by Post Malone. It’s unfinished, featuring Post mumble as he attempts to lay down the melody. Details about the song are largely speculative, however, it’s thought to have been recorded sometime around or after sessions for Post’s 2018 release, beerbongs & bentleys. It leaked online on April 12, 2020.

description.plain: “For Me” is an unreleased collaboration between Post Malone and Tory Lanez. The origins and details of the song are largely unknown, though it’s thought to have been recorded during sessions for beerbongs & bentleys. The song was put up for auction by Music Mafia on May 18, 2018; it’s unknown if it will ever see the light of day.

description.plain:
“Big Lie” appears on Post Malone’s debut album, Stoney. This, however, is an early version of the song featuring Ty Dolla $ign.

This demo of the song features a verse from Ty Dolla $ign following the flow of Post in place of his second verse. It’s unknown why his contribution was removed from the final version of the song. It leaked online on January 13, 2019.

description.plain:
“Don’t Make Me” is an unreleased song from Post Malone. The full song leaked online on April 30, 2020. The song is believed to have been produced in 2018.

Not much is known about the song, but the song does feature the mumbling that is present in many of Post’s unreleased songs, which he uses as reference verses. The second verse is also left open, suggesting Post may have wanted someone to feature on this track.

description.plain: “Guacamole Carpet” is an unreleased song by Post Malone. A now-deleted low-quality recording of the song was leaked in 2015, meaning it was possibly created during early sessions for Stoney. In 2018, a higher quality snippet of the song was acquired from Music Mafia and leaked online. The full song leaked in high quality on January 18, 2019.

description.plain:
“Feel” is a collaboration between Post Malone and Kehlani that appears on Post’s 2016 effort, Stoney. This is an early version of the track featuring Rita Ora that leaked online on September 28, 2019.

This version of the track has Rita in place of Kehlani, featuring an entirely new bridge that was later utilised as the outro on the final track. The instrumental also feels unfinished, with the track overall feeling slightly slower.

description.plain:
“Belong to Me” is an unreleased demo of Post Malone. It’s unfinished, featuring Post mumbling and recording scratch vocals in a similar way to the previously-leaked “Trembling”.

Details about the song are largely unknown, however, judging by the vibe of the song, it was likely recorded after Stoney. A snippet of it was leaked online on May 8, 2019; it’s unknown if the full thing will see the light of day.

description.plain:
“New York” is an unreleased song from Post Malone that surfaced online on April 21, 2020. It is unclear how old the song is, but some speculate it is from around the time when beerbongs & bentleys was made.

Post’s words are mostly scrambled mumbling, which can be referred to as a reference song.  It is used to help him remember certain melodies or flows that work well with a song, which he can then revisit later to add actual words to. Kanye West did this with his verse in an early version of “Internet.”

description.plain: “Wow.” was the last piece of work released by Post Malone in 2018. This is an early version of the song, featuring Post mumble as he attempts to create a flow as is typical with several of his demo tracks; its instrumental also sounds unfinished. It leaked online on June 4, 2019.

description.plain: “Problems” is an unreleased throwaway demo by Post Malone. It’s unfinished, featuring Post mumble as he attempts to lay down the melody. Details about the song are largely speculative, however, it’s thought to have been recorded sometime in 2018 after the release of beerbongs & bentleys. A snippet of the track leaked online on December 11, 2019, with the full track following on April 12, 2020.

description.plain:
This is an early version of “Enemies”, the DaBaby-assisted third track of Post Malone’s 2019 album Hollywood’s Bleeding. It leaked online on February 27, 2020.

As is typical with many demos, the song features Post mumbling as he lays down a rough idea for the track both melodically and lyrically. The Louis Bell-produced instrumental also appears to be less developed compared to the final release, and DaBaby’s verse is absent.

description.plain:
“Ric Flair” is the name given to a series of unreleased collaborations between Post Malone and Swae Lee; this is a solo demo by Post that leaked online on September 4, 2019. As is typical with many demos, it finds Post freestyling and mumbling as he attempts to lay down a melody.

Multiple versions of the song were recorded in 2017, but no iteration ever saw an official release. An alternate version of the track with Swae Lee and an intro from Ric Flair leaked online on June 19, 2019. Another version that remains unleaked contains extra vocals from Swae.

description.plain:
This is an early version of “Internet,” the 13th track from Post Malone’s 2019 release, Hollywood’s Bleeding. A snippet leaked online on November 7, 2020.

Like many demos, the track finds Post mumbling as he attempts to lay down a rough idea for flow and lyrical content. It was recorded in 2015 during sessions with Kanye West; he appears on a later demo from the same sessions, but was ultimately cut when the track was reworked and released in 2019.

description.plain:
“Frances Farmer Will Have Her Revenge On Seattle” is a cover of the 1993 Nirvana song of the same name.

Post Malone released his version during his 2020 “Nirvana Tribute” Livestream on YouTube amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The song, along with other covers of Nirvana material, was performed to raise money for the World Health Organization.

description.plain:
“Lithium” is a cover of the 1992 Nirvana song of the same name.

Post Malone released his version during his 2020 “Nirvana Tribute” livestream on YouTube amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The song, along with other covers of Nirvana material, was performed to raise money for the World Health Organization.

Post previously performed the song during a surprise Coachella appearance in 2016.

The finest day that I've ever had

Love myself better than you
